Situation1: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Expectation2: Teach children about Jewish traditions, values, and history
Situation2: A weekly study slot is planned, and lessons could be shifted without losing continuity.
Story: I pulled up to the curb, the meter still running, and watched as two travelers struggled with their mountain of suitcases. They waved me over, asking if I could help load their bags and if they could split the fare. I nodded, already calculating the time it would take. As a taxi driver, I prided myself on being helpful and professional—going the extra mile for my passengers was part of the job. But as I reached for the first suitcase, my phone buzzed with a reminder: the weekly study session with my kids was about to start. Teaching them about our Jewish traditions and history was something I cherished, a responsibility I took seriously. I knew the lesson could be shifted, but I also knew how much my children looked forward to our time together. Standing there, suitcase in hand, I felt the weight of both roles pressing on me—my duty to my passengers and my commitment to my family. I hesitated, torn between the expectations of my job and the values I wanted to pass on to my children.
